content:
Blue Bottle Coffee is a fantastic brand, and it's great that you've been recommending it to your audience.

To track your YouTube live stream analytics, you can use YouTube Analytics, which provides insights into your channel and video performance. Here's how to access and use YouTube Analytics to track your live stream performance:

1. **Sign in to YouTube Studio**: Go to youtube.com and sign in with your Google account. Then, click on your profile picture in the top right corner and select "YouTube Studio" (beta).
2. **Navigate to Analytics**: In YouTube Studio, click on the "Analytics" tab on the left sidebar.
3. **Select the "Live" tab**: In the Analytics dashboard, click on the "Live" tab to view your live stream performance.
4. **Choose a time period**: Select a time period for which you want to view your analytics. You can choose from pre-set options like "Today," "Yesterday," "This week," or a custom date range.
5. **View your live stream metrics**: On the Live tab, you'll see various metrics, including:
	* **Concurrent viewers**: The number of viewers watching your stream at the same time.
	* **Peak concurrent viewers**: The highest number of viewers at any given time during the stream.
	* **Average view duration**: The average time viewers spent watching your stream.
	* **Watch time**: The total time viewers spent watching your stream.
	* **Engagement**: Likes, comments, and other interactions on your stream.
6. **Drill down into individual streams**: If you want to see analytics for a specific stream, click on the stream title in the list. This will take you to a detailed analytics page for that stream.
7. **Use the "Compare" feature**: To compare the performance of different streams, click on the "Compare" button at the top of the page and select the streams you want to compare.

By analyzing your YouTube live stream analytics, you can gain insights into what works and what doesn't, and adjust your content and streaming strategy accordingly.

Additionally, you can also use third-party tools like TubeBuddy, VidIQ, or Hootsuite to track your YouTube analytics and gain more insights into your channel and stream performance.
